review_title: Good for Tuition Remission and Benefits
pros:
Great tuition benefit! Paid for my Masters. Can also use tuition benefit for Continuing Education (fitness, cooking, hobbies, professional development), certificate classes, and fitness.
Annual leave benefit is hard to surpass-- all employees get 14 hours/month of annual leave and 8 hours/month of sick leave. Nice winter break.
Great deals on Popejoy and Lobo season tickets.
cons: Parking is ridiculously expensive and you still have to park far. Insurance is high and not very flexible. It's easy to get stuck in a position because there's not a lot of opportunities for advancement within your departments. It doesn't pay (literally) to stay in the same position in your department -- you're better off to leave after a couple of years to negotiate a better salary or else there's not much opportunity for increases. For a few years, my take home pay kept decreasing due to increased employee contribution to benefits, even with small raises.

job_title: Public Health Consultant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: There are some good, hardworking people (Faculty and staff) and the main campus is a pleasant environment
cons: A lot of incompetance at every level, especially among the upper administration. Human Relations is a good example. Call to ask a question about a policy or benefits and you are subjected to a snotty attitude, as if they were doing you a favor instead of their job. This department takes an extremely ham-handed and punitive approach to job discipline issues after overseeing and accepting the results of so-called "investigations", and violates its own policies on a regular basis, including terminating employees to shine up the institution's tarnished image caused by their own mismanagement. Salaries are lower than they should be, benefits are fair but I would think long and hard about accepting an offer to work at UNM.

pros:
There is free tuition up to 6 credit hours/semester. Sadly, employment rules only allow you to use 4 (and all courses are divided into 3-credit-hours).
There used to be a free gym. Closed with covid.
Cant really say anything else good about working here.
cons:
This is NM's largest employer and largest "institution". It is full of your textbook NM nepotism, corruption, double-standards, fraud, and incompetence.
People that work here are generally people who cannot get jobs in the private sector - of course, since NM has no high-skill private sector - you see what I mean...
Having worked in world-class companies in California, Europe, etc - I was quite appalled at the incredibly unprofessional, unskilled, incompetent people working here as well as the culture that believes corruption, nepotism, fraud, and so on - are normal and acceptable.
If you speak up or actually try to achieve something while working here, these typical new mexicans will get on your case hardcore because it is their culture to be incompetent, corrupt, nepotistic etc.
That is why they cannot leave NM as they would never be able to survive in the real world.
Federal grants and federal jobs paying 1/2 of what they would anywhere else in the country is what keeps NM's economy alive. I guess at the federal level they still think its worth it... I have a hard time believing it however.

UNM is also a very racist insitution. If you arent hispanic, generally in NM - you will suffer racism in every facet of life - and UNM espouses and completely supports this culture - while pretending to be "inclusive". Something they talk about frequently, and yet they openly support neo-nazis and islamists (as in terrorist islamists who are literally running terrorism funding on campus).

The university retirement is through the NM Education Retirement Board, and it’s pretty good. Annual leave and sick leave are separate pools of paid leave and it accumulates rapidly. Tuition remission is available. The benefits are worth any reduction in pay you might face.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Albuquerque, NM
pros: For the most part clinical staff work hard and well together. I have never been told to give VIP tx to someone, every patient is treated well. They try to promote from within and there is a union. The night shift and weekend diff is very good. If you work at least 30 hours a week, the insurance (which is only UNMH and only fair) is included as a benefit.
cons: The Occupational Health program is a problem and their decisions on many things are arbitrary, illegal (know employee who won court case against them) and illogical. They "top out" their pay scale at 15 years, so any experience beyond that does not receive a real raise. Raises are minimal and do not keep up with inflation. The worst issue is that administration (definitely not leadership) does not seem to truly understand what they are supposed to be running. For example, when Covid first hit, they decreed that the respiratory therapists could not be given N95 masks. This job is the extreme front line but admin did not know what they did, hint it is in the name.

review_title: They own you on a meager salary and will exploit you for cheap labor.
pros:
Free housing, sometimes a whole apartment or dorm room with a bathroom.
Partial meal plan - lasts about 1/2 the semester.
Work from home.
Can be fun and rewarding, meet cool people and make friends.
Excellent job for emotionally intelligent and artistic people.
Some room for career growth.
cons:
Very poor pay and paid monthly; you will need a second job to meet your other living expenses.
UNM Housing has reduced the value of the meal plan compensation for this position to half its previous value in the last two years.
Forced to sign a contract that obliges you to fulfill your outlined RA duties and "all other duties deemed appropriate by your supervisor". This clause in the contract is heavily taken advantage of and you will often be asked to provide extra labor at no additional pay.
Fishbowl effect - you are constantly being watched, especially at home.
No work life balance, job is 24/7, your "customers" are your neighbors.
Emotionally taxing position that can leave you traumatized.
No mental healthcare, insurance, etc.
Absolutely horrendous, weeks long training process in which you will be infantilized and will be taught nearly nothing about how to deal with a crises until the final day. You will be expected to show up on weekends and your work days during these weeks will be at least 12 hours long.
No raises for increased experience in the Resident Advisor position.
Your housing is tied to your employment. If you want to find a different job, you will need to arrange alternative housing first.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Albuquerque, NM
pros: I have a young and growing family and the benefits have been great for us. The education benefits have been amazing. I've used tuition remission every semester for great continuing education classes. My wife was able to get the dependent education scholarship and have her tuition paid for. The department I work in is very caring and understanding. There are always new positions for my field across the university, so there looks to be great opportunities for movement and/or growth on campus. This was my first employer when I moved to Abq and it has been a wonderful, secure employment that my family and I have appreciated.
cons: My pay isn't terrible, but I do wish salaries across the board would increase. The benefits help offset this but still think many of the salaries out there are too low. The biggest con is that many departments seem to be overworked. It seems like the university doesn't do much to help with this, other than push for more student worker help. My department (one of the smaller on campus) is definitely overworked. I can feel it quite often and I can see/hear how stressed my colleagues are at times and can only imagine what it's like for larger departments on campus.

pros: The tuition remission benefit is wonderful! Great health benefits, my department is very supportive and supports work-life balance. Great jobs for students who are interested in getting through their degree programs while getting paid. Vibrant university community and events. Opportunity to make friends at work (in my case, at least). I really appreciate and enjoy the networks I have made thanks to my position and department.
cons: University bureaucracy can limit growth for people with potential. Ladder-style promotion process is lengthy and seems antiquated. You will have to do work that is not in the position description. You may have to do extra work without compensation or recognition for your work. Can feel like the worker is being taken advantage of. High turnover rate in administrative positions. No in-depth training. Much you must learn by trial and error or by asking questions to other overworked employees. There is low overall staff morale because of this. Raises are few and far between, when they are offered, they are very small bumps. My department depends on appropriations from state legislature--sometimes this is a complicated, political process. Budget cuts depending on state revenue or grants. Be prepared to work hard, but learn a lot. I think this is a good job for entry-level employees to learn the pros and cons on their own. Depending on the department, management/administration can be unorganized, lacking clear communication, lacking direction. It all depends on the department and the manager of that department.

review_title: The University of New Mexico is a good place to work.
pros: The best reason for working at the University of New Mexico is the benefits.  You get free tuition for some classes when you work full time (and I think when you work part time as well), and this extends to your spouse/significant other and children.  The vacation time is exceptional by an employer.  And there is deferred compensation for retirement, if that interests you.  The new president of UNM, President Schmidy, seems to me to be very open with faculty and staff.  I am very impressed with him and his communications with faculty, staff and students.
cons: A full time, exempt employee gets paid only once a month.  This is a big thing to adjust to!  Plus raises tend to lag behind all other employers in the Albuquerque area, so over time, unless you can get a promotion, you will fall behind.  And I think that promotional opportunities are not very good for individual contributors.

review_title: UNM offers great opportunities for building a career, retirement, and educational credentials all at the same time.
pros: UNM has great benefits which include winter break, paid leave, employee tuition remission, and dependent education.    Because it is a large institution, there are plenty of opportunities to build skills and develop your career in a variety of roles.  There are so many opportunities if one chooses to see them and pursue them.  It's also a beautiful campus with many spots to sit and enjoy.
cons: It can be hard to get "in", to get a job at UNM, but once you're in you can get to know people and move into other positions.  Knowing people is often key to getting positions.  And, you can hit a pay grade level that seems impossible to break through.  Some departments are not supportive of staff taking classes, which seems odd for an institution of higher education. Many  people complain about the pay being too low, but that's why you need to plan to move to other positions - so you can also build your salary.  Also, if you want to get rich, don't work in education!  It can also be a frustrating place to work but, again, manage your expectations because it is a bureaucracy, after all.

job_title: Analyst Programmer III in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: I worked for UNM for several years. What I liked about it is the work I did was both challenging and interesting. That the people I worked with were for the most part good to work with. The benefits are just some of the best you'll find anywhere. The opportunity for training and educational options is good, since this is a university. Other non-profits will do nothing for you, as far as training goes. UNM is much better at this.
cons: The pay is sub-par compared both to someone doing the same thing in the private sector and I believe other educational institutions. One thing that you need to be aware of, if you're a salary employee, is that you get paid just once a month. The last business day of the month. When I first started I wasn't made aware of that. Believe me when I say that we were starving days before the end of the month since we didn't have any cash for simple things like food. So long as you know you'll get nothing until the end of the month, you'll be better off.

job_title: Graduate Student Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The jobs vary with department and advisor, so I'll concentrate on the location!  Albuquerque is a great place, lots of outdoor activities and weather is usually good- plenty of sun!  UNM is a good place to collaborate with Sandia National Labs- can get real research done.  Friendly academic environment- easy to talk with people from any department for a few minutes.  Sunny place with few rainy days, so easy to walk to work with a variety of inexpensive housing nearby.  Very multicultural and friendly- a decent amount of music, a decent amount of fairly decent fairly inexpensive restaurants- especially for various types of spicy food.
cons: The hours can be long, the pay can be low.  Working with Sandians can be disheartening- they earn pretty well.  There's a strong dimension of strange favoritism, with things other than usefulness being rewarded (an undergrad making $40k for half time general lab assistance while studying? similar to research profs!)  Funding can be a bit flaky sometimes- mine never disappeared, but sometimes there were strange hiccups that had to be corrected by my advisor using his "pull."  Pull works, whether good or bad is debatable.  Sometimes it gets *hot*.  There's not much of a retail environment, if that's important.  There are a few people with trouble with diversity- but most embrace it.

cons: The pay is quite low

pros: Convenient if you live on or near campus, proximity to Albuquerque and classes. tuition remission if you're faculty or staff. very easy hours, most people are 9 to 5, but some get away with 9 or 10 to 4, depending on where you are at. Student employment rules limit you to 30 hours a week, so work-life balance is really easy.
cons: Lower than average pay if you're a student. They figure that if you are willing to be a student-employee, they can stick it to you and make you pay for the convenience of working near the place you live. Management can be iffy, but like any place else, they have both ends of the  spectrum when it comes to management quality. High turnover of all employees. Students obviously don't stay at one job for long, but staff tend to move around a lot also.

pros: Experiences necessary to work in academia, like teaching/tutoring in higher ed and conducting research, health insurance provided, some tuition is covered
cons: PhD students have no accrued time off, most often do not get offered to teach over the summer (so no money coming in over the summer), have to find their own GA/TA/RA/PA-ships and cobble them together from several different departments, usually only able to obtain a 0.25 FTE (10 hr/wk) with stability (while expected to complete courses and dissertation), no dental or vision benefits, enrollment/departmental fees are not covered once a PhD student becomes a PhD candidate, get paid the last business day of every month (so learn how to stretch your monthly budget), new contracts every semester (so no guaranteed employment for the entire academic year), most assistantships are for either a 0.25 (10 hr/wk) or 0.5 (20 hr/wk—if you’re lucky to snag one of these) FTE, expect to earn $7,000/semester for every 0.25 FTE you work, GA/TA/RA/PAs cannot work more than a 0.75 FTE (it is extremely rare that you can find an assistantship that has you at 30 hr/wk anyway), do not receive overtime pay, if you help with research do not expect your name to be included in publication

review_title: Experiences vary. Red tape is incredible. Efficiency?  What's that?
pros: The University is pretty comprehensive and strives to remain relevant.  There are lots of collaborative initiatives with the local community, businesses, government, etc.  U.N.M. does a great job of promoting their programs and services.
cons: Extremely slow and cumbersome processes and procedures cause a great deal of lost time and unnecessary effort. Behind the times as far as IT is concerned (embarrassing, really).  Culture is hyper-competitive among faculty. There is a huge divide between Faculty and staff. I've witnessed a huge amount of back-stabbing, virtually no mentoring, low morale, playing favorites and senior faculty sabotaging junior faculty.  Also, the pay levels are very low compared to similar institutions.

pros: Full assistantships also cover tuition. You get a lot of different experience as a research assistant because you can work for more than one professor and they take your interests into account when assigning you to work on a project. You are entrusted with a lot of the data and dataset management. You get to lead your own discussion sections as a teaching assistant so you aren't just a grading machine.
cons: The pay is low, but so is all graduate student pay. Some professors do not respect the part time hourly limit of assistantships and expect you to perform way more work than you possibly can in 10-20 hours per week. You also don't get very much credit for the work you do.

No checks and balances. Staff & faculty lack a voice in organizational decision making processes.

review_title: Benefits are "OK", pay is low, raises are non-existent, upper management arranged to give themselves secret bonuses.
pros: Good annual and sick leave allowances, free tuition for 8 credits per semester, job stability, generally nice people to work with across campus.
cons: Low pay compared to private industry, non-existent raises for the last 5 years, department director and associate directors arranged to give themselves "secret" bonuses becuse of all the "extra" work they do.  Staff actually do the extra work, but they get the pay!  Good luck getting the time off during the day to use the tuition benefit.  Some department managers consider it a "nights only" tuition benefit.

pros:
I was required to do more than the industry norm for my job title and this added to my skill set. Tuition remission perk is great as well as vacation and sick time.  
The classes I took here were a joy. Good sense of University community. Beautiful campus.
cons: Managers get away with everything and are not laid off or fired. There is no recourse for an employee who suffers a  manager who is a bully. The pay is low and the benefits cost more every year. There is usually a hiring freeze. The stress for meeting  deadlines was intense. Very poor life/work balance. Not a very friendly or supportive place to work.

review_title: My time at University of New Mexico Service Corps  was completely satisfying.
pros: The company had a very organized way of placing a person where they could thrive. The process to join was relatively easy, and fast paced. They gave everyone the tools they needed to do their best. U.N.M.S.C. had a variety of programs all designed to give back to the community. Because of the way the program was set up, they gave a stipend at the end of a term if you completed your hours.
cons: You could only work for them for four years. Also, you had to be enrolled in UNM as a full time student.

job_title: Tenured Associate Professor in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Friendly staff, sunny, great weather, mostly bike-friendly campus. Not much else good to say.
cons:
Administration loves to recruit minority faculty, but only wants you for photo ops and as an asset for grant applications, don't really care about what you can contribute to the campus environment.  This is a minority-majority campus, but not reflected in the faculty, and not valued from a pedagogical perspective. Bureaucracy prohibits true intellectual development of ideas and research, the IRB process is a nightmare.  Don't come here if you want to do research. Once you get tenure, it's all committees, all the time. 
Benefits package is good, but price goes up every year. The PERA program is a scam- the university pulls all it's contributions if you don't stay until retirement.

pros: Lots of sun, diverse population, beautiful natural surroundings, cool local culture
cons: Non-competitive salary/ benefit packages (no cost-of-living adjustments, much less raises, in years as health insurance fees rise), aggressively anti-faculty Board of Regents, no shared governance or transparency, bloated and overpaid upper administration, lots of frustrating and incompetent bureaucracy to negotiate for faculty who take on service roles at any level. The only way to get a raise is by getting a job offer from elsewhere (and most then wisely leave). I love NM and my students, but b/c of university governance UNM is a pretty awful place to teach and do research—there’s a consistent upper-administrative climate of distrust and scorn towards faculty and their work.

review_title: A great place to work for your mind, maybe not so much for your wallet.
pros: The University of New Mexico can be a great place to work.  The people are educated and engaging.  There are plenty of opportunities to learn new skills.  Tuition remission gives employees the benefit of academic, professional development and health education at very little cost.
cons: Staff employees have not had a substantial raise in over eight years.  During my five years with UNM I have seen my take home pay go down due to increases in health care and retirement contribution requirement increases.  It has gotten so bad for some of the lower level staff that the staff council opened a food bank.

pros: Part-time employees get full benefits. It's a job in a place where aren't many jobs... that's about the best thing I can say
cons: Part-time employees pay twice what full-time employees do for health insurance. I have worked for you and him for more than 5 years, and I have never received one cent of a raise. I work hard and accommodate everyone's requests for help in a cheerful manner M eanwhile,  rude faculty members who don't even answer their emails receive promotions, awards and bonuses. The chronic budget shortfall means lower-level employees have to do more work when people resign and their positions are not refilled. But you don't see the upper-level managers sacrificing their salaries or having to do more work.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, paid time off for winter break, ERB pension benefits.
cons: UNM has severe budget problems.  You may go for several years without a salary increase while the cost of your benefits continue to increase every year.   Because of the budget problems many vacant positions are not filled, creating more workload for the staff that remains.  It is difficult to advance to another position because there are few positions that are open for hiring.

job_title: Analyst Programmer II in Albuquerque, NM
pros: This is a great place to work if you are incompetent and enjoy being bullied and sexually harassed by jealous bullies. Human resources ignores all complaints about violations of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.
cons:
The pay is low and the benefits are sparse. As state employees, the benefits should at least match those of other state employees in other sectors.

My one-star rating is far too generous. I wish I could give a negative five stars for willfully violating the civil rights of employees and refusing to discipline the bullies who bully on a daily basis without doing any productive work at tax payer's expense.

pros:
As a Student you get to choose your own hours for the majority of positions
Many positions pay very well
Most positions let you study in your downtime at work
cons:
Bureaucracy often gets in the way of productivity
It seems like most staff really hate working there, they probably stick around because of benefits, or because they prefer to take the path of least resistance.

review_title: A good place to work if you enjoy teaching and aren't in medicine just for the money.
pros: Excellent support from the EM Department chair.  Outstanding staff & physicians with whom to work.  Many opportunities to teach and opportunities exist for personal and professional growth.  The department allows a reasonable amount of flexibility in shift scheduling and supporting teaching interests at the School of Medicine
cons: Somewhat heavy academic/shift demands given the yearly faculty salary; UNM Emergency Medicine physician salaries are in the lowest 25% in the nation

review_title: Mixed experience overall. Positive relationship with direct supervisor. Experienced discrimination from admin/HR
job_title: Associate Scientist I in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Diverse campus, lots of interesting work being done for New Mexico and nationally on the HSC campus. Direct supervisor allowed me to work remotely, flexible hours.
cons: Reported sexual harassment to HR/admin and was told I overreacted/misinterpreted the actions of my accused, and was then forced to continue working with this person, until he threatened and stalked another young woman in the workplace and bragged about having sex with teenagers as a 40 year old (while at work). UNM does not handle reports of sexism adequately, and my experience was not unique

review_title: The security of the public sector isn't worth the unhappiness of working there.
job_title: EEO Compliance Specialist in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Excellent benefits package.  Opportunities for advancement for those that choose to stay at UNM.
cons: Working in the public sector is very different than working in the private sector.  In the public sector, people have jobs for life, so many people lack energy, enthusiasm, interest in doing things better, and, frankly, the skills required to manage people and do their jobs well.  Because the environment is so stagnant, good people don't stay in the public sector--they leave.  This results in excessive bureaucracy and exceptionally poor customer service.  Also, the pay is terrible, but that's not the primary reason I left this job.

review_title: Incredible benefits IF you can get hired on as a permanent employee
job_title: User Support Analyst II in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The University offers retirement, tuition remission, paid holidays, vacation, and the list goes on.
cons:
There must be some kind of secret handshake to become hired on as a permanent employee.  I've worked in 4 different departments since 2007 (6 years) and am still a temporary employee.
Another HUGE con is that they don't pay very well.  There are many competent people that should be getting paid at least twice the amount of money they're earning now.  On the other hand, there are many people are are overpaid based on their competencies.

pros: Stable work, very little effect from a down economy (except lack of pay raises).  Nice people to work with for the most part, tuition remission for 8 college credit per semester and time off (3hrs per week) to take classes, 14 hours of annual leave and 8 hours of sick leave accrual each month (pretty generous),
cons: Relatively low pay for the metro area for most jobs (Except custodians that make a more than average to get people to apply), employer provided insurance is WAY too high given the size of the workforce (7000+) since smaller employers in the area have cheaper plans,

pros: Laid back employer style -which can be nice from the frentic corporate pace in the real world. However, that laid back style can drive you nuts when you work there. Committee's can last for 2 years or more. Very expanded benefit and paid time off allowances. Probably the best I've ever had. Christmas holidays the campus closes down plus a generous PDO plan and retirement plan. Generous glass attendance during work hours.
cons:
Intertia
Union 
State Government pace
Crime in ABQ in general
Expensive to live there
Common issues with having cars parked at UNM vandalized or out right stolen.

pros: Vacation & benefits, but it is Not worth poverty level pay unless you are desperate
cons: poor & lazy employer,  low moral, no raises, racism across all departments, locals less likely to be considered for promotion, they don't hire based on talent and skills, hiring is based  exclusively on degrees and if you are white,  which results in low level mediocrity,  at the very best.

review_title: Great job security for permanent positions, but only if you can cut through the bureaucracy.
pros: If you can get your foot in the door, this is an amazing place to work, with great job security.  It's easy to stand out amongst your peers if you put in the hours and your work shines, due to laid-back nature that is fairly prevalent in Albuquerque.
cons: Because it is a university, it is extremely difficult to obtain a permanent position.  They are compelled to post external job listings, and interview n number of external candidates, even when there are internal candidates who are more than qualified for promotions.  Grant funding is touch and go.

review_title: All the bureaucracy you'd expect from a government institution disguised as a university.
pros: Once you're in, it's very unlikely you'll get fired for anything, including sexual harassment of the student employees. Free education for employees and their children.
cons: Don't expect to get promoted or raises based on merit.  You will need to be very comfortable working through red tape and dealing with people who clearly don't expect to be held accountable for anything.

review_title: If you don't mind the pay, UNM is a great place to work
job_title: Analyst Programmer I in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The individuals here are all very talented, hard working, and nice to work with. They are very flexible about time off. They actually respect the opinions of lower level employees.
cons: Lower pay, but it can't be helped. It is a state-funded university after all. Depending on which team you end up, the work can be a little boring unless database security is your thing.

review_title: Good place to work, just make sure you network outside of the school.
pros: Access to government labs (Sandia and Los Alamos) as well as the Santa Fe Institute.  Skiing is great in this part of the country, and the weather is wonderful.  Lots of great hiking and outdoors stuff in general.  You get paid the same RA rates as other schools in the country, but Albuquerque is very inexpensive.
cons: UNM is not as well known as some other schools.  Crime is a bit of a problem.  Your car is likely to be broken into or stolen entirely.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: It provides an optimal experience for students who wish to work part time such as TAs and RAs. Also, most student related jobs cover tuition and some insurance. UNM is quite welcoming and tolerant to people of different races, gender, religions, etc
cons:
Parking can somethings be a problem especially having to pay for parking as faculty / staff.
The wireless network on campus is also problematic in some cases.

review_title: The work experience at UNM brings both ecstasy and agony.
pros: The variety of persons, culture, interests, and levels of expertise is complex and daunting, at first. Eventually, one adjusts and gravitates to those most beneficial and rewarding.
cons: The system can be very rigid and unforgiving and as such, resists growth, development and achievement, both for itself and the individual. The focus of the head of my Department tended toward control, rather that management of resources.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in UNM, NM
pros: The University of New Mexico is a great place to work if you are a student that is trying to juggle courses and work hours. Nearly all available positions will work hard with you to sort out a schedule that works for both yourself and your on-campus employer.
cons: The only downsides to the student jobs at UNM are that oftentimes the hours are few and far between. Pay is fairly standard, and if you're working as a clerk or in retail, you're not likely to see too much above minimum wage.

review_title: A nice place to work for a year or two, but don't expect any career opportunities.
job_title: Associate Scientist I in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Outstanding Annual Leave and Sick Leave policies.
cons:
In research positions, there is 0% chance for advancement without switching jobs.  You are NOT told this up front.

Raises do not remotely keep up with cost of living increases.  In real terms, I have become financially poorer every year I have worked at UNM.

review_title: Better than it thinks it is
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Good graduate program, with very active research and exciting stuff going on. Close ties to the excellent medical school mean lots of data for scientists to work with.
cons: UNM has some of the worst self-esteem I've ever seen at a university. No matter how interesting the research is, it seems like the students and faculty never give themselves enough credit for it. The administration used to be pretty incompetent, but this is turning around lately with the new president.

job_title: Technical Support Analyst I in Albuquerque, NM
pros: UNM offers some of the best soft benefits in town.  Time off and flexible work hours make it extremely attractive.  The work is good: supporting learning and education is always rewarding.
cons: Salaries are low with no COLA raises for over 5 years.  Internal politics are terrible in IT with rivalries and personal ambitions getting priority over what is good for the University.

review_title: Laid back atmosphere, don't expect to get rich working there.
pros: laid back, usually nice bosses, usually good bennies and retirement, work/life flexibility, hot college girls everywhere, public universities aren't too results oriented
cons: low salaries, raise freezes, often hiring freezes, old grumpypants coworkers that have been there for years and are only 'working' until retirement kicks in, too many administrators that prevent actual work by happening by having neverending meetings about said work

review_title: Watch out for department directors who are politically connected
pros: Good time off and benefits, free classes, nice campus
cons: Unfortunately this university does not always hire department heads based on their qualifications or experience.  Sometimes high level positions are given to people with strong political connections. This has created disastrous results for the safety department since all of the qualified and experienced employees have left, many of them going to work at other universities.  This is also very unfortunate for the students and employees at UNM since the campus is much less safe.

review_title: It was supportive at the time and situation, but not a place I would want to stay at long term.
pros: The atmosphere reflects that of the state, which means there is more of a laid back attitude. The focus is more focus creativity and open dialogue.
cons: Sometimes it is too laid back to the point of unprofessionalism. The pay is abysmal, as with other entities in New Mexico, in comparison to the cost of living (which is not cheap).

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The position that I held with UNM was one filled with daily change and something new.  It was not a position with one job description, I held a number of hats and I loved the challenges that the job presented.
cons: Being able to adjust to constant change, variety in jobs, demanding deadlines..I

job_title: Full Time Lecturer in Albuquerque, NM
pros: As a full-time lecturer I had the opportunity to teach without research requirements and minimal issues with the politics of tenure-track. I felt supported my departement and enjoyed working with departments across campus. I really enjoyed the student population and campus. I didn't find anything  negative about UNM that wasn't present on most college campuses. You can supplement salary with summer and interim teaching.
cons: There is not much rom for growth in salary in this position. Department and university service are expected. Academic politics.

review_title: Great place to get a paid graduate education in science
pros: Flexibility and relaxed environment. People seem very happy to be here. Newer facilities. close to lots of restaurants. casual dress. friendly people
cons: parking, pay rate, a handful of catty folks. it would be really nice if the departments were fuller. not enough collaborations

review_title: It was a wonderful experience, and the pay was pretty good... for a student job.
pros:
Great if you're a student; flexible schedules, some jobs provide an on-campus office space.
Academic environment promotes independent thinking.
Helps pay for college when work-study is available.
cons:
No benefits for student positions.
Limited hours.
HR resources are limited for student positions.

pros: UNM IT Classroom Technologies had a great team, and management was respectful and easy to work with. If you worked hard you would be appreciated. If you took initiative your ideas would be listened to and possibly promoted.
cons: low expectations for employees, if you didn't self-motivate you could easily get away with a poor work ethic.

review_title: Friendly, laid back environment. Good benefits and generous time off"
pros: The benefits are affordable and pretty good. The non traditional benefits are great as well. The environment is pretty laid back and easy going.
cons: A bit disorganized as far as management goes. It can be unclear what each persons job is and easy to scapegoat. Communication is lacking between departments and conflicting information is giving out.

review_title: A Great Place to Work and Study
pros:
New Mexico's Flagship University and a Carnegie classified Very High Research institution.  
I really enjoyed my time there and retired as a director.  One of the best benefits packages in New Mexico.
cons: Parking can be congested, but well organized and there is a free shuttle service than runs every 15 minutes from outlying surface lots.

review_title: Great Benefits & work life balance, but the money and people are below average
job_title: Certified Anesthesiologist Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Great Dental benefits and retirement plans
cons: Not a very cohesive group. Lack of leadership and care for employees. (Except Dr. Doran, she is pretty amazing)

pros: Good people that care about patients and believe in good teaching for medical students, residents and fellows.  Pay is competative for the area and there is plenty of moonlighting if you want it.
cons: Could be more organzied, more administrative support would be good, advancement can be limited since it can take a long time to more from mid to senior level.

pros: Best thing in university of new Mexico  is living in Albuquerque, especially weather and sandia peak.  All most people doing administration work are willing help you out.
cons: People working here all are friendly. However, they can not give a lot useful advise or real help. And some opportunities can be accessible through your personal network easily.

review_title: Diverse student population not reflected in managerial staff
pros: The University of New Mexico offers convenient exposure to unique cultural experiences. The weather in Albuquerque is second to none, with over 300 sunny days annually.
cons: Several departments within UNM appear to communicate well however the majority of departments appear to operate independently of one another, thus resulting in a waste of resources and a disservice to students.

job_title: Marketing Officer and Public Relations Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Great chance for educational advancement as well very friendly for those who have a family. Even with the wonderful benefit package, the salary/income is competitive.
cons: If the economy is rough, UNM has the ability to not give raises until the books come into the black again. That can be rough but they make up for it. As staff the focus is NOT EVER ON YOU OR YOUR SKILLS, OR WHAT YOU CONTRIBUTE ... it is ALWAYS about how you apply to helping faculty or students.

review_title: Overall a good place to work.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Diverse.  The good researchers are there because they want to be in the area.  Proximity to many national labs and applied science.
cons: Too much administration.  There is a lot of corruption in the high level administration.  The university is a bit too much of a business.   It could be a better ranked research institution if there was more effort put in.

job_title: User Support Consultant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: I've had great supervisors.  It's a pretty laid back place to work that will schedule around your classes.  Pays well for a student job.
cons: Mostly customer service.  Not learning as many technical skills as I would have liked for an entry level IT job. Taking calls can always be draining.

review_title: You could do worse in Abq
job_title: Staff, Not Faculty in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Slow pace, some benefits, regular work hours, lots of trees on campus, education benefits, better than a lot of places you could work locally, will probably be around next year
cons: Decaying buildings, slow pace, low pay, academic environment, state likes to chip away your pay and benefits, staff are second class citizens to faculty

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Flexible work hours, welcoming environment, ability to progress in ranks, and benefits for staff members.  UNM offers opportunities to further your education while employed.
cons: At times it may seem like you are not being utilized to the best of your abilities, however, that was very rare. Some work schedules are not desirable hours.

job_title: Office Assistant in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: I really enjoyed the friendly and peaceful work environment.  Working with disabled students is hard work and the Accessibility Resource Center at UNM does a great job.
cons: There were some problems within the department.  I thought that there was a huge lack of communication between student employees and staff members in the department.

review_title: Equal mix of good and bad
pros: There are a decent amount of perks, such as tuition remission, discounts, campus activities, and job safety(for the most part).
cons: If you are a hard worker, you will notice more and more that the people around you are not. Most get by doing the bare minimum. This can cause a slowdown in your work. In addition, there is a lot of uncertainty and sometimes low employee morale. But overall not a bad place to work considering.

job_title: Information Technology Professional in Gallup, NM
pros: Small campus, so get to know most everyone. Also get to work on every aspect of IT as we do not have/need a team for each aspect as a result of the small campus. Customers are generally friendly. Plenty of learning and networking opportunities.
cons: Since it is such a small campus and we have a small staff, it is easy sometimes to be overwhelmed with work orders, specifically when we are trying to update/replace a large amount of equipment.

pros: Excellent benefits, great co-workers, super providers.
cons: Administration and higher not so great. No impetus to change situations that clearly aren't working. Reporting to managers who have no idea what you do and no way to manage or review you. Meeting just to meet with no results.

review_title: You can't go wrong with dedicated students, down-to-Earth-coworkers, and good benefits to boot.
job_title: English As A Second Language Teacher in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Learning about students' cultures, gaining teaching experience, learning how to better serve my students, and building lasting friendships.
cons: Although it is an excellent job there really isn't a way of becoming tenured or being at CELAC longterm. Most people use it while working on masters and doctoral degrees and then move on.

pros: Great location. Affordable cost of living.
cons: Little concern for staff. No raises for years for staff and highly inflated salaries for upper management. The only way to get more money is to leave your job and move to another unit. When you leave. They hire a new person at an increased salary. Very poor business model to force qualified, knowledgeable staff to leave a position to get that increased salary.

pros: Flexible schedule that is tailored to the life of a student. Great opportunity to network with the university staff and faculty. Relevant experience.
cons: Work can be unpredictable at times and is often distributed during the beginning and end of the semester. Depending on the assignment, the tasks can become repetitive.

pros: Nice place and weather to work and live. Good orgnization offer help for international students. Many benifits like public traffice is free for UNM student.
cons: Research facilities are not enough. Not too many opportunies can be found in industry here. Not easy for international students get chance to national labs.

job_title: Program Director Operations in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Less of a corporate mentality: generally speaking, workers aren't treated simply as an easily disposable; Benefits are good (vacation& retirement).
cons: Academia-Hours worked very on a daily to weekly basis, but expect to bring your work home, often (depending on what you end up doing). Working in administration / leadership you do not have summers off unlike faculty and students, depending on what you do. Not as many perks as a corporation.

pros: I have found the University to, overall, be an enjoyable and open atmosphere in which to work, where open discussion was allowed (your department/college may vary)
cons: Almost complete lack of training or communication to the ever-rotating door of adjunct faculty which seems to be an increasing norm in the public college sphere

job_title: Assistant Data Manager in Albuquerque, NM
pros: The UNM system has great benefits and a decent work environment. The HR department is on-the-ball when it comes to communicating policy changes or new opportunities.
cons: The upper administration is top-heavy and self-serving. Changes to staff and faculty benefits are often made without appropriate consideration of input from those affected.

pros: Partial tuition remission is nice, despite it does not cover fees at all.
cons: Human Resources department is the absolute worst.  They took over 8 weeks to get a student job in the system so I could work (in a 16 week semester).  What's worse, they continually require students to re-submit documentation each semester (are they loosing it or unable to keep track of sensitive information?).

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Great opportunities for learning and professional development.  Great opportunities for career growth.
cons: Much of the executive staff are longtime employees who get used to one system and one way of thinking.  This can be a stumbling block to innovative thinking.

review_title: Beautiful place to live and work in general.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Scenic landscapes all around. Very very low cost of living. International airport close by. Good quality of life. Good work/life balance.
cons: As the largest employer in the state, it is a huge bureaucratic jungle. Getting anything done administrative wise is a nightmare.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
Great Leave policy
Up-to-date equipment (Computers, Printers, etc)
Safe working environment
Tuition Remission ($1,800) per year
Professional development/continuing education
cons:
Parking ($124) per year
Property stolen from vehicle 
Low pay
Expensive benefits package (PPO)
Retirement fund is mandatory (7%)
Cannot advance unless you change positions

review_title: I'm a research assistant faculty in Dept. Chem. My job is very time-demanding so I have little knowledge of my employer.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
Large, comfortable, beautiful. 
The service here is excellent.
cons:
It's library is always without books what I want.
It increased fees to improve the library (part of the increased fee, other parts including the supply to athletes.) this year, but the amount aroused complaint of undergraduate students.

review_title: The UNM IT Applications Manager Position is a positive career opportunity
job_title: IT Applications Manager in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Tuition remission if you're faculty or staff, quality of life to address family needs, and highly collaborative working environment with TONS of  vacation time!
cons: The Executive VPs provide outstanding leadership as does middle management.  A majority of the leadership positions in between seem to lack business acumen and rely on conniving politics.

job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Caring, flexible schedule, fast hiring process, helps pay for school, friendly environment, space is respected, and i make my own schedule.
cons: Limited hours. Hurdes under student employment so i have to be enrolled at UNM in order to work, little to no pay increase, no chance to grow in the work environment/position.

pros: Benefits package with great pay are awesome as a university employee . Great place to work and perks for employees are wonderful.
cons: UNMH Shuttle did not transport employees to and from project echo.  Aside from the shuttle issue UNM is a wonderful place to work.

pros: There are some truly dedicated, wonderful people at UNM, who do their best on a daily basis to try and overcome the serious management and personnel issues for their colleagues, students, and assistants.
cons:
The compensation is abysmal unless you're hired into administration or management, and the routine increases in tuition, decreases in benefits, and increases in costs without a cost of living adjustment will drain you completely dry, financially.

The incompetence at Accounting, Student Advisement, and the Bursar's office will keep you running, trying to keep track of sensitive paperwork on your own. This will and does impact your salary, getting your paycheck in a timely fashion, your health care benefits, and access to grants or funding. On several occasions, they "lost" my entire file, lost my contract, lost my benefits, and lost my funding paperwork, leaving me scrambling or without pay for months while they sorted it out. I learned to keep my own copies of paperwork and obsessively check, which makes productivity effectively nill, since not being paid for months is a bit preoccupying.

Some of the faculty and management are not just indifferent to the welfare of students, junior faculty, and employees, they're downright malicious. In the thirteen years I spent at UNM as first student and then employee, I repeatedly witnessed bullying behavior enacted by tenured faculty and management against junior faculty, students, and employees. HR did precisely nothing about it, and on occasion actually censured anyone who dared to file. The net result in some departments is an atmosphere of fear, distrust, and a breakdown of anything resembling collegiality, in which the tenured faculty and management with issues were given fairly free rein to behave in any way they saw fit by the inattention, disinterest, and inability of HR to intervene. I witnessed a considerable amount of talent be driven away by entrenched faculty and management.

The facilities themselves (the physical buildings and equipment) are often antiquated and in poor repair, with plumbing dripping from ceilings in the bathrooms of some buildings, sometimes for years without much repair work being done. The campus itself is poorly lit, and once you leave the newer math, science, and engineering facilities on the south part of campus, you rapidly run into dysfunctional elevators, bathrooms, and a myriad of structural issues and vandalized lights/police call boxes. The campus badly needs broad repair work, and while it's nice that the math, science, and engineering facilities were improved, the rest of the campus really needs some love.

While I worked at UNM, I also witnessed very little interest in working with students, employees, or faculty with disabilities. Some buildings on campus are extremely difficult for disabled students to access, and as a rule, very few people in administration or management cared whether or not disabled students had ADA mandated access to facilities.

Finally, work-life balance was awful. It was not uncommon for me to end working double my contractual hours due to rampant disrespect of contractual restraints, often while being told that if I wanted to be taken seriously as a scholar, student, or employee, I would work for free on various projects.

review_title: Excellent stepping stone opportunity, short term
pros: Autonomy in course design and planning. Encouragement to teach a wide variety of courses.
cons:
Administration opted to NOT pay SSI, an option for Graduate Teaching Assistants. 
Administration and technical support for materials development is scant to nonexistent.
